CHRIS HANNAH: Hi.
I'm Chris Hannah.

I'm the head bartender
here at the French 75
Bar, New Orleans, Louisiana.

The French 75 Bar is a classic,
cozy New Orleans bar hidden
inside the French Quarter.
It gives you that old feeling.

It's like old New
Orleans nostalgia.

You walk in and you think
you're back in time.

It goes along with the
music in play here,
which is 1920s French jazz.

And you sit down, have
a classic cocktail,

and you're just taken
back to a bygone era.

One of the wonderful things
is you could be a character
here in New Orleans.

And be part of this play
that I call New Orleans.

And so my job is to be a
bartender at the French 75 Bar.

What inspires me is
most of the history

of New Orleans, different
characters, but also reading.
I read a lot of books.

And then if I really
like a character,

and like what this character
drinks, where they're from,

and I get ingredients from,
like, maybe that country

or wherever the
story takes place,

and something that
relates to it.

French 75 is a champagne
cocktail with cognac,
lemon juice, little sugar.

You know, I believe that
the Lafayette Escadrille
created the French 75 cocktail.

They were a allied fighter
pilot outfit in World War I,
the Americans and the French.

And when they would
go on their raids,

they would come back
safely and thank

the French 75-millimeter
cannon for their safe journey.

And they would drink
champagne and cognac together.
Yeah, I started in the kitchen.

You know, six years
in the kitchen.

And what's helped me in
creating these drinks

was the flavors that I
learned, and how to make sauces
and actually develop a palate.

A drink I recommend to guests
for a first time, something

new, something, you
know, very New Orleans,
I would say the Brandy Crusta.

Brandy Crusta is the first
sugar-rimmed cocktail,

actually, and it was created
like three blocks from here.

There's cognac,
bitters, Angostura

bitters, maraschino
liqueur, orange curacao,
and lemon juice.

Since I'm an old
soul, I want them

to experience the
vibe and energy
of what I really kind of like.

You know, I moved here because
I love Louis Armstrong,

1920s, the way people dressed.
